Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C (Uniform Child.raw_text: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C (Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act) (jurisdictional provisions)
Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C (Uniform Child.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody and parenting plans may be modified upon a showing that there has been a material change in circumstances affecting the best interests of the child since entry of the prior order.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody and parenting plans may be modified upon a showing that there has been a material change in circumstances affecting the best interests of the child since entry of the prior order.

Macomber v. Dillman, 421 Mass. 87 (1995).raw_text: Macomber v. Dillman, 421 Mass. 87 (1995) (courts consider best interests; material change standard)
Macomber v. Dillman, 421 Mass. 87 (1995).proposition: Courts have long held that where parental conduct or changed circumstances materially affect a child’s welfare (including schooling, health, or emotional stability), the court may modify custody or parental decision-making authority to protect the child’s best interests.
Macomber v. Dillman, 421 Mass. 87 (1995).case_name: Neff v. Commissioner of the Department of Industrial Accidents
Macomber v. Dillman, 421 Mass. 87 (1995).support_reasoning: This opinion concerns workers’ compensation procedure and the authority to waive an impartial medical examination fee for indigent claimants. It does not address child custody, parental conduct, material changes in circumstances, or judicial modification of custody/decision-making to protect a child’s best interests. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition about modification of custody or parental decision-making authority.
Macomber v. Dillman, 421 Mass. 87 (1995).relevant_excerpt: On examination of the procedural path described above, it becomes apparent that the Legislature created a system whereby an employee either pays no fee or may have a fee waived for indigency at any point in the dispute except at the stage when an impartial medical examination is mandated. If this examination is not obtained, the proceedings halt and the claimant’s benefits are discontinued. G. L. c. 152, § 11A (2). The plaintiff could not go on to the next stage of the dispute.

Tropea v. Tropea, 409 Mass. 19 (1991) (b.raw_text: Tropea v. Tropea, 409 Mass. 19 (1991) (best interests analysis)
Tropea v. Tropea, 409 Mass. 19 (1991) (b.proposition: Courts have long held that where parental conduct or changed circumstances materially affect a child’s welfare (including schooling, health, or emotional stability), the court may modify custody or parental decision-making authority to protect the child’s best interests.
Tropea v. Tropea, 409 Mass. 19 (1991) (b.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal procedure/search and seizure case about whether an investigatory stop based on an anonymous tip met the reasonable suspicion standard. It does not involve custody, parental conduct, changed circumstances, or any best-interests-of-the-child analysis. Citing this case for authority on modification of custody or parental decision-making to protect a child's welfare is therefore inaccurate and unrelated to the proposition claimed.
Tropea v. Tropea, 409 Mass. 19 (1991) (b.relevant_excerpt: To meet the “reasonable suspicion” standard in this Commonwealth, police action must be “based on specific, articulable facts and reasonable inferences therefrom” rather than on a “hunch.” Commonwealth v. Wren, 391 Mass. 705, 707 (1984), and cases cited. Thus, if the police conduct an investigatory stop based on an informant’s tip, our evaluation of the tip’s indicia of reliability will be focused on the informant’s reliability and his or her basis of knowledge.

Sullivan v. Crippen, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 2.raw_text: Sullivan v. Crippen, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 262 (1991) (modification principles)
Sullivan v. Crippen, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 2.proposition: Courts have long held that where parental conduct or changed circumstances materially affect a child’s welfare (including schooling, health, or emotional stability), the court may modify custody or parental decision-making authority to protect the child’s best interests.
Sullivan v. Crippen, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 2.case_name: Burlington Sand & Gravel, Inc. v. Town of Harvard
Sullivan v. Crippen, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 2.support_reasoning: The opinion in Sullivan v. Crippen as provided is not about custody, parental conduct, or modification of parental decision-making authority. It concerns municipal zoning enforcement, the availability of civil penalties under G.L. c. 40A § 7, and the effect of a preliminary injunction on later prosecutions. It therefore does not address, much less establish, principles governing modification of custody or decision-making based on a child’s welfare, schooling, health, or emotional stability.
Sullivan v. Crippen, 31 Mass. App. Ct. 2.relevant_excerpt: There is nothing in the language of the injunction itself that prohibits the prosecution of Burlington for violations of the zoning by-law while the injunction was in effect. Further, “[t]he purpose of a preliminary injunction is to maintain the situation in statu quo until the merits can be determined.” Thayer Co. v. Binnall, 326 Mass. 467, 479 (1950). The granting of the injunction against Harvard did not compel Burlington to use the access road in a manner that violated the zoning by-law.

Kluge v. Hennessy, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 337.raw_text: Kluge v. Hennessy, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 337 (1987) (parental conduct and child welfare)
Kluge v. Hennessy, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 337.proposition: Courts have long held that where parental conduct or changed circumstances materially affect a child’s welfare (including schooling, health, or emotional stability), the court may modify custody or parental decision-making authority to protect the child’s best interests.
Kluge v. Hennessy, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 337.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about suppression of evidence, legality of a Terry stop, consent to search, and related trial issues. It does not address family law, child custody, parental conduct, or modification of parental decision‑making based on a child’s welfare. Therefore it cannot be authority for the proposition concerning modification of custody or parental authority due to changes affecting a child’s welfare.
Kluge v. Hennessy, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 337.relevant_excerpt: The entire opinion concerns a defendant’s conviction for receiving stolen property and related suppression and trial issues; there is no discussion of custody, parents, children, or best interests of a child. Accordingly, no excerpt is relevant to the claimed proposition.

Pimental v. Pimental, 72 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Pimental v. Pimental, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 300 (2008) (modification; material change)
Pimental v. Pimental, 72 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Courts have long held that where parental conduct or changed circumstances materially affect a child’s welfare (including schooling, health, or emotional stability), the court may modify custody or parental decision-making authority to protect the child’s best interests.
Pimental v. Pimental, 72 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns trespass to land and damages for unlawful tree cutting under G.L. c. 242, § 7, and the Land Court’s jurisdiction to award such damages. It does not involve custody, parental conduct, children’s welfare, or any modification of custody or decision-making authority. Therefore, it does not address, much less support, the proposition about modifying custody based on changes affecting a child’s welfare.
Pimental v. Pimental, 72 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: This case contains no discussion of child custody, parental decision-making, or children’s welfare. The core issue is summarized at the outset: “a decision of a judge of the Land Court to award treble damages to the plaintiff landowner on her claim that the defendants cut down trees on the plaintiff’s land. … [T]he Bergmanns… had wilfully cut down the trees… and trebled damages under G. L. c. 242, § 7.”

Murdock v. Murdock, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 33.raw_text: Murdock v. Murdock, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 338 (1995) (parenting time modification cases)
Murdock v. Murdock, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 33.proposition: Courts have long held that where parental conduct or changed circumstances materially affect a child’s welfare (including schooling, health, or emotional stability), the court may modify custody or parental decision-making authority to protect the child’s best interests.
Murdock v. Murdock, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 33.support_reasoning: This decision is about procedural error in entering an adoption-decree judgment on an issue not tried, and about relief from judgment under rule 60(b)-type standards. It does not discuss modification of custody or parental decision-making authority based on changed parental conduct or changed circumstances affecting the child’s welfare. Any references to best interests or unfitness are in the context of termination of parental rights, not custody modification, so the case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Murdock v. Murdock, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 33.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the department that there was clear and convincing evidence to support the judge’s findings that the mother was currently unfit to further the child’s best interests and that a decree allowing the department’s G. L. c. 210, § 3, petition would have been proper — if that had been the issue that was tried.… If the department changes its goal as it did here, it should bring a separate G. L. c. 201, § 5, petition and enter a voluntary dismissal of the G. L. c. 210, § 3, petition.”

Capone v. Capone, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 398.raw_text: Capone v. Capone, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1998) (parental decision-making disputes)
Capone v. Capone, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Courts have long held that where parental conduct or changed circumstances materially affect a child’s welfare (including schooling, health, or emotional stability), the court may modify custody or parental decision-making authority to protect the child’s best interests.
Capone v. Capone, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal drug case addressing the validity of an ‘any person present’ search warrant, admissibility of drug evidence, and sufficiency of evidence for intent to distribute. It does not involve custody, parents, children’s welfare, schooling, health, emotional stability, or modification of parental decision-making authority. Therefore it provides no support for the quoted family-law proposition and appears to be a miscitation or miscoded case reference.
Capone v. Capone, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: In executing a search warrant in Peabody for the premises of Jason Ward, which also “commanded [the] search [of] any person present,” police searched and arrested the defendant who then was in the living room with others. The police found nine small packets of marihuana and about four hundred dollars in a pocket of his pants. The defendant later was convicted by a District Court jury of possession of marihuana with intent to distribute (G. L. c. 94C, § 32C). He raises three issues in this appeal. We affirm.

Duquette v. Duquette, 72 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: This case is a Massachusetts criminal appeal involving aggravated rape, kidnapping, and related evidentiary and ineffective assistance issues. It does not involve child custody, visitation, or any modification of parental rights based on a child’s welfare or changed circumstances. Nothing in the opinion addresses family law standards or best-interests analyses, so it does not support the cited custody-related proposition.

B.L. v. M.L., 75 Mass.
